H0.text: Lipid is the class of molecule to which an enzyme in the Golgi apparatus catalyzes the addition of phosphates.

H1.text: Carbohydrate is the class of molecule that an enzyme in the Golgi apparatus catalyzes to receive phosphates.

H2.text: Nucleic acid is the class of molecule to which an enzyme in the Golgi apparatus catalyzes the addition of phosphates.

H3.text: Protein is the class of molecule to which an enzyme in the Golgi apparatus catalyzes the addition of phosphates.

A4.text: The synthesis of Phosphatidylinositol (PI) is limited to the Endoplasmatic Reticulum (ER), which is the largest membrane component of the cell.

A5.text: Phosphatidylinositol (PI), also known as inositol phospholipid, is a lipid composed of a phosphate group, two fatty acid chains, and one inositol molecule.

A6.text: The Golgi apparatus adds a mannose-6-phosphate label to proteins destined for lysosomes.

A7.text: Phosphorylation of oligosaccharides on lysosomal proteins occurs in the early CGN.
